column2: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 17 Mickey Rivers has seen Bobby Murcer go home again, and Rivers wants to do so, too.

MACAO, March 17 (Reuters) China has approved Macao's plans to build a billion-dollar airport, Governor General Nuno Melo Egidio said today. Access to Macao, on the south China coast, is now by hydrofoil from Hong Kong, 40 miles to the east.

Brig. Gen. Herbert D. Gibson, a veteran of both world wars, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital at First Avenue and 24th Street. He was 88 years old. He had retired from the Army in 1946 because of disability and lived in Manhattan.

LONDON Michael, who is 29 years old, has been searching for his natural mother for nearly a decade. The task has included weeks of sifting through dusty files; months of painstaking research in 20-year-old telephone directories, election registration lists and adoption agency records, and costly trips to London, where central records are kept. Twice Michael has come to a dead end by locating someone else's natural parent by mistake.

The basic measures of the money supply rose strongly in the week ended March 12, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The market had expected little or no change in the money supply and the disappointing figures led some analysts to predict that the Fed might again tighten the money supply and credit.
Two Italian brothers were arrested in New York early yesterday morning at the request of the Italian Government on charges of fraudulent bankruptcy.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- One supporter of increased Federal aid to New York City refused to compromise. Another was attending a dinner to honor Walter Cronkite and missed a key vote. CAIRO -- Four prominent American corporations, boycotted by the Arab world for dealing with Israel, are among 60 United States companies participating in Cairo's 13th annual trade fair, now drawing to a close. They have been lured by Egypt's growing potential as a market for Western products.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- As a result of a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals ruling, it will be several years before children 10 to 12 years old may be hired by farmers to pick crops where there is a danger of pesticide exposure.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Department of Energy has set a voluntary gasoline consumption goal for this spring that calls on Americans to use 3.4 percent less gasoline in April, May and June than they did a year ago.

Wednesday whether to end a voluntary moratorium by exchanges on the expansion of options trading. Prices in the credit markets continued to slide yesterday under the pressure of heavy borrowings announced by the Federal Government. The markets' decline over the last two days more than wiped out gains made earlier in the week.

LINCOLNTON, N.C., April 1 (AP) Two men have been sentenced to prison for a cross-burning on the lawn of a home. One of the men, Virgil Griffin, is the grand dragon of the North Carolina Knights of the Ku Klux Klan. The other man, Mark Sherer, pleaded guilty to cross-burning and possession of a firearm by a felon.
BOITO'S "Mefistofele" has been a fixture at the New York City Opera since 1969 something of an anomaly in the operatic world because this work is rarely performed anywhere else outside Italy.

CAIRO, April 1 As the deposed Shah of Iran convalesces from surgery, most Egyptians seem to have accepted his presence as a humanitarian necessity, although a few have expressed concern about how long he will remain in Egypt.

CEDAR CITY, Utah, April 1 The census workers were out trying to take their part of the national snapshot today and were finding it hard to get everyone to hold still and say cheese.
MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, April 2 President Carter won a landslide victory in Wisconsin's Democratic Presidential primary yesterday while Ronald Reagan won by a narrower margin in the Republican contest.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) A key Senate committee today effectively blocked any action on aid to the bankrupt Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad in a dispute with the House over large passenger train improvements.

BARI, Italy, April 1 (AP) A 33-yearold man and four sons aged 7 to 14 were found dead in their home today of apparent food poisoning, the police reported. The children's mother was in a hospital in serious condition. Doctors were testing food found in the house to determine the exact cause of death, the police said.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 1 All last week Eddie Gregory was saying, "Light-heavyweight champion of the world," as he answered the telephone. This morning, now that he was at least half-champion, he puffed his chest and talked about perhaps becoming the heavyweight champion, too.

If fried, poached or scrambled eggs seem too mundane as representations of this Easter symbol for breakfast next Sunday morning, consider instead eggs in the somewhat more decorative and festive forms represented here.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., April 1 (AP) Pfc. Alvin Williams, an Army parachute rigger, was charged today with murdering Capt. Lawrence D. Hill, 26 years old, whose parachute failed to open in a jump because one of its lines had been cut.

The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan said yesterday that it would continue financing exports of its automobiles to the Chrysler Corporation in April because Chrysler and seven Japanese banks had not reached an agreement on credit arrangements.

PARIS, April 1 The arrest in France last weekend of 22 suspected terrorists, including five Italians, has disclosed for the first time the effectiveness of a coordinated European effort to combat terrorism.

With three weeks remaining in the television season, CBS-TV again has pulled into a tie with ABC-TV in audience averages for the season to date by scoring a decisive victory last week. CBS's prime-time programming, led by "Flo," "M*A*S*H" and "60 Minutes," had a 20.3 Nielsen average for the week, compared with 18.5 for ABC and 15.8 for NBC-TV.

PARTLY because of sharply rising matzoh prices, the cost of the foods in the Department of Consumer Affairs market basket rose in the latest period to a record $92.57, up 0.96 percent, or 88 cents, over the previous period and 4.27 percent from the comparable period a year ago.

HARTFORD, April 1 (UPI) Connecticut's Catholic bishops say the way to slow increasing teen-age pregnancy and veneral disease rates is to teach youngsters the virtue of chastity instead of the prevention of contraception.

DALLAS, April 1 (AP) The executive board of the Major League Baseball Players Association voted today to cancel the remaining exhibition games of spring training but agreed to open the regular season on time a week from tomorrow.

LUSAKA, Zambia, April 1 Leaders of nine black African nations held a brief conference in Lusaka today and agreed on a seven-point plan designed to diminish their countries' heavy dependence on South Africa.

WHEN H.M.S. London docked in New York on Operation Sail four years ago, the vessel's astonished stewards were besieged by expatriate Britons in des perate search of a real English sausage. This was only one item in a long list of much-missed foods from home.

SAN SALVADOR, April 1 Five gunmen opened fire on Guatemala's Ambassador to El Salvador today as he was driving down a street here, but a protective vest deflected the bullets and he was only slightly injured.

DETROIT, April 1 (AP) A group investigating Wayne County's financial troubles has concluded that the nation's third-largest county fails to keep track of its taxpayers' money and allows its Civil Service Commission to wallow in "patronage, cronyism and favoritism."
The air in Manhattan was cleaner than usual yesterday, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 1 President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr said today that Iran's Revolutionary Council "will accept the control" of the American Embassy hostages if the United States formally promised not to say or do anything hostile until after the as-yet-unelected parliament makes its decision on the hostages' fate.

LANSING, Mich., April 1 (AP) The Rev. Norman A. DuKette, the oldest black Roman Catholic priest in the United States, died yesterday at St. Joseph Hospital here. He was 89 years old. Father DuKette, pastor of Christ the King Church in Flint from 1929 until his retirement in 1970, was ordained in 1926 in Detroit.

TOKYO, April 1 (AP) Japan used 1.81 billion barrels of oil in the fiscal year 1979, 5 percent less than the predicted level of 1.9 billion barrels, the International Energy Agency said today. The saving of 94.3 million barrels matched the Government agency's conservation target of 5 percent set at an agency ministerial meeting in Paris last May.
MILWAUKEE, April 1-Mayor Henry W. Maier was elected to a sixth term by a comfortable margin tonight, turning back a challenge by Dennis Conta, who won the nonpartisan primary by 71 votes in February.

"THE Left-Handed Woman," the first film to be directed as well as written by Peter Handke, the Austrian novelist, playwright and poet of alienation, is a beautiful, mysterious and somnolent film that leaves you even as you are watching it.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The House of Representatives approved legislation today to allow Volkswagen to open an auto assembly plant in Michigan. Leaders of the Transport Workers Union were ordered yesterday to face possible contempt-of-court charges in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn tomorrow for violating two court orders enjoining the strike that shut down the city's buses and subways.
The Cosmos' worldwide search for a forward to complement Giorgio Chinaglia apparently has ended.

ANCHORAGE, April 1 (AP) Winds gusting up to 120 miles an hour caused extensive damage early today in Anchorage, Eagle River and Wasilla, knocking out electricity in some areas for more than five hours, officials said. No injuries were reported, however.

WASHINGTON, April 1 President Carter said today that he was deferring plans to impose new economic and political sanctions on Iran in the expectation that the American hostages would soon be transferred to the control of the Iranian Government.

Rates on Treasury bills, after declining sharply for two and a half trading days, bounced upward yesterday as the money market tightened enough to push the Federal funds rate to 20 percent and caused major banks to increase their prime rates as high as 19 percent.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The Senate Commerce Committee said today that it would not negotiate on a billion dollar railroad improvement bill passed by the House unless a $105 million passenger-train project was dropped from the measure.

SEVICHE is a Mexican dish composed mostly of raw fish marinated in lemon or lime juice, and its delicate taste accented by the tartness of the citric marinade demands a crisp, dry yet fruity white wine. The seviche of sea scallops and mussels prepared here the other night by Chef Gottfried Troger for a special banquet at Pierce's 1894 Restaurant was served with a seyval blanc 1978 from Clinton Vineyards.

DETROIT, April 1-The Ford Motor Company, beset by slumping domestic vehicle sales, plans pay cuts for its white-collar workers and more layoffs, including as much as 10 percent of its support staff, according to sources within the company. The number of workers affected by layoffs is expected to run into the thousands.
LOS ANGELES, April 1 Construction of the Los Angeles Museum of Modern Art will begin at the end of 1981 and be completed in 1982, the museum's founding trustees announced today.
The Greater New York Blood Program appealed for donors yesterday, saying that 75 percent of its scheduled donations for today had been cancelled.

DETROIT (AP) April 1 The Justice Department today confirmed a disclosure by the General Motors Corporation that a grand jury investigation of the automobile maker's Federal tax return has languished for nearly two years with no signs of being revived.
SIGNS are increasing that the economy's inflationary fever is breaking. Treasury bill rates have dropped from about 16 percent a week ago to 14.90 percent in yesterday's trading.

DENVER, April 1 (AP) The Johns-Manville Corporation, in a suit with wide significance in the product liability area, said today that it had filed suit against 18 insurance companies that have provided, or are providing, the company with coverage for injuries allegedly arising from excessive exposure to airborne asbestos fibers.

NEWARK, April 1 Marvin Ellison, the alleged ringleader of the attempted escape and 16-hour siege at the Essex County Jail last week, has been placed under tight security at the State Prison in Trenton following his sentencing here yesterday to 25 years for the slaying of two Newark men.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) House Republican leaders unveiled their own plan to balance the 1981 budget today, calling for deep cuts in domestic spending, a large increase for military spending and a $32 billion tax cut.
WASHINGTON, April 1 Business and labor exchanged the opening salvos today in a legislative battle that could determine the future role of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) The Senate voted by 91 to 4 today to cut back the Interstate Commerce Commission's power to regulate the nation's railroads, giving the industry more freedom to raise freight rates. The bill was sent to the House.

Arthur Kleiner, former musical director of the Museum of Modern Art and an accompanist and composer of music for silent films, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Hopkins, Minn., near Minneapolis. He was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 29 "We need a minor cultural revolution in this country and you have to bring it about," Representative Paul Simon, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Select Subcommittee on Education, told a gathering here this weekend.

LONDON, April 1 The executive committees of the two largest unions in the British steel industry voted today to accept a pay increase totaling about 17 percent, and workers were ordered to return to their jobs at the British Steel Corporation on Thursday.
William D. Schwartz, vice president of Prescott Ball Turben, securities brokers of 1 Battery Park Plaza, died yesterday of a brain tumor at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 36 years old.

QUINCY, Fla., April 1 (UPI) Circuit Judge Ben Willis said today that it would "shock the conscience of this court" to let an elderly black couple lose their home because they forgot to pay a $3.05 tax bill. He voided the deed of a white speculator who bought it for about $100.

Chris Evert Lloyd, who began a vacation of indefinite length on Feb. 1, said yesterday that she would play in the Italian and French open tennis tournaments next month.
DETROIT, April 1 (AP) The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would close its Eight Mile Outer Drive stamping plant here by the end of 1980 and would transfer its work to other facilities.

WASHINGTON Official attitudes toward arms-sale policy are shifting again. Many deals that should be avoided are filtering through a bureaucracy that is no longer deterred by President Carter's policy, as expressed in 1977, to sharply curtail weapons transfers.

TOPEKA, Kan. April 1 (AP) Kansas Republicans voted overwhelmingly for Ronald Reagan today in the state's first Presidential primary while Democrats gave President Carter a comfortable victory over Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.

LOCK HAVEN, Pa., April 1 (UPI) The Piper Aircraft Corporation, a large general aircraft manufacturer, today announced a two-week shutdown in three states and the layoff of 5,200 workers, some of them indefinitely.

LONDON, April 1 (AP) The International Sugar Organization's council today set the global free market basic export quotas for the next three years at 15,520,112 metric tons, up from 15,275,000 for the first two years of the 1977 International Sugar Agreement.

Others seem to be shuffling these elements like cards in a deck, rather than adding something of their own to the tradition.

Judge Irving R. Kaufman is to be honored in Manhattan tonight at a dinner commemorating his 30 years as a Federal judge.

WASHINGTON, April 9--For some of those who believe that the Shah, and the status quo, could somehow have been preserved in Iran, Henry Precht had become something of a villain. Such critics saw the 47-year-old Foreign Service officer as too soft on, and friendly to, the diverse forces of the Iranian revolution.

WASHINGTON, April 9--An upstate New York town has been awarded a $3.5 million Federal grant that is intended to be combined with the private investment of $18 million to build a plant to manufacture American copying machines now being made in Japan.

CLEVELAND, April 9--A Federal district judge who has wrestled with the Board of Education here for seven years over integrating the city's public schools says he is considering imposing "serious sanctions" against the school system.

Alhough the transit strike is bruising the city's economy more with each passing day, many of the city's business leaders yesterday urged Mayor Koch and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to remain firm in the negotiations.
The top administrative judge of New York City's courts and a justice of State Supreme Court are involved in a bitter dispute over allegations of judicial impropriety and incompetence.

WASHINGTON, April 9--In the opening round of what is shaping up as a battle in bombast, a Ralph Nader-led coalition of consumer and labor groups disclosed a list today of 11 major corporations it charged with committing "crime in the suites."

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., April 9 (AP) --The 82d Airborne Division has revamped its parachute-packing procedures for tighter security after an Army officer fell 1,200 feet to his death, apparently because of a tampered chute.
Louis Petri, one of the nation's largest wine producers and a former owner of the Italian Swiss Colony and the Inglenook vineyards, died Monday in San Francisco. He was 67 years old.

The Chrysler Corporation said in Detroit yesterday that it had extended indefinitely its effort to sell $230 million in convertible debentures to the company's dealers and suppliers. The offer was scheduled to expire earlier this week. The No. 3 auto maker did not indicate, however, how close it was to its selling target.
The weekly American Petroleum Institute figures do not appear today because of a delay in statistics gathering. The figures are expected tomorrow.
The credit markets, after continuing their recovery yesterday morning, lost some of their recent enthusiasm for lower interest rates yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI)--The Federal Communications Commission today proposed to change the method by which communications companies competing with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company pay A.T. T. for using certain of its facilities.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI)--The five Federal agencies that regulate the nation's financial institutions asked Congress today to give them wideranging powers to deal with a severe recession.
IF the exterior of your house is sided with stucco, now is the best time to repair any cracks that may have opened in the surface during the winter.

Squeezed by high costs and stiff competition, the United States Steel Corporation wants protection from imports. It has broken rank with other large steel producers to file "dumping" complaints against seven European countries for selling steel in this country below cost.

For the first time since the transit strike began, negotiators for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and members of the executive boards of the two striking unions met yesterday, and they focused on critical and unresolved issues.
IF you have recently rediscovered the bicycle as a mode of transportation, you may be interested in some useful bicycle accessories that can hold a briefcase, groceries, laundry or even children.
WHEN last we heard of David Garnett, he was romping in the raspberries with Mina Curtiss, who re ported on the romp in her delightful memoir "Other People's Letters."

BOSTON, April 9--The Boston Celtics have been talking about their "impossible dream"--a National Basketball Association championship--for some time now, and tonight they took a big step toward its realization by soundly defeating the Houston Rockets, 119-101, in the first game of their Eastern Conference semifinal series.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 9--The Casino Control Commission today granted the Bally Manufacturing Corporation a five-month extension of its temporary casino permit and approved expansion of its Park Place Casino in an attempt by Bally to improve profits.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, April 9 (UPI)--The New York Stars, led by Pearl Moore with 27 points and Janice Thomas with 22, captured the championship of the Women's Basketball League tonight by defeating the Iowa Cornets, 125-114.

WASHINGTON, April 9--Two Democratic Governors strongly defended President Carter's economic policies today before the party's 1980 platform committee, even to the point of approving his elimination of the $2.3-billion-a-year state portion of the Federal revenuesharing program.

WASHINGTON, April 9--Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., the brokerage firm that was shaken by the recent fall in silver prices, has suffered another setback with a lawsuit filed today against a Nashville-based broker and a group of investors by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ST JOHN'S, Antigua, April 9 (Reuters) --Antiguans will vote April 24 for a new parliament. Premier Vere Bird made the announcement last night at a meeting of the Antigua Trades and Labor Union, which supports the ruling Antigua Labor Party.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)--President Carter said today that he would nominate James Edward Sheffield, a Richmond judge, and James Harry Michael Jr., a Virginia State Senator, to be Federal district judges in Virginia.
WASHINGTON, April 9--The problem of acid rain and what to do about it is generating conflict between states in two different regions of the country.
The 1980 season at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass., the summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, will begin on June 26 with a series of chamber-music concerts in the theater-concert hall.

Major league baseball returns to New York today after a six-month absence, with Craig Swan pitching for the "new" Mets against Rick Reuschel of the Chicago Cubs in a curtain-raiser that may be depopulated by the city's transit strike.

GARDENERS going through their seed catalogues this year found flowers that are normally more at home in America's fields and roadsides than in domesticated flower beds--tickseed, purple cornflower, black-eyed Susan and blazing stars--being prominently offered for sale. The wildflower has suddenly become a best seed seller.

One of the most remarkable maneuvers in bidding is the Striped-Tail Ape Double. The idea is to double opponents who are on their way to a slam that will succeed before they reach it. If they meanly redouble, the doubler flees swiftly to the safety of his own suit, alternating aggression and discretion just like the anthropoid after which the double is named.

MIDDLETOWN, Pa., April 10 Public relations is the art of making the most of the undeniable. A good demonstration of this can be seen here at the Three Mile Island visitor's observation center overcooking the gravely damaged nuclear reactor, where the pictures on the wall have been changed to emphasize President Carter's visit of a year ago.

There is still a chance for New York's welfare families to receive a small grant increase. The Assembly has passed a bill calling for a 10 percent boost in the basic allowance, and Governor Carey says there's money to pay for it.

DURING late 1979 and early 1980, when natural resource stocks enjoyed a buying boom, the popular reasoning on Wall Street held that vir tually anything in the ground could provide a hedge against inflation. Thus, investors scampered after companies with a stake in oil, natural gas, gold, silver or copper.

MOSCOW, April 10 (Reuters) A Soviet ballet dancer who defected to the United States and then returned home was quoted by the Soviet press today as having said that American intelligence officers tried to enlist him as a spy.
Dr. Robert H. Fowler, a retired surgeon who directed his own hospital in Manhattan for 20 years, died Wednesday in a nursing home near Stuart, Fla. He was 96 years old and lived in Stuart.

George Carlin, he of the sharp tongue and mild manner, was chatting about comedy the other day, and the idea came through that it is not so much that he has caught up with the times as that the times have caught up with him.

HOUSTON, April 10 (UPI) Eddie Dibbs and Bill Scanlon breezed past quarterfinal opponents today and set the stage for their first match on clay in the $175,000 Houston stop on the World Championship Tennis circuit.
A Federal judge in Brooklyn ordered Governor Carey yesterday to ask the State Legislature for $342,000 to continue the operations of the review panel at the Staten Island Developmental Center.

RAMALLAH, Israeli-Occupied West Bank, April 10 Palestinian college students charged today that they were cut and beaten by Israeli soldiers who stormed their school yesterday, shouting about revenge for a terrorist attack earlier this week in which three Israelis died, including a child.

At least two persons died in the torrential rains that swept into the New York metropolitan area Wednesday and early yesterday morning, forcing the removal of dozens of families from flooded homes and stranding hundreds of motorists.

Two concerts scheduled for tomorrow night have been canceled or postponed. The "Cushion Concert" of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo will not be given because the floor space has been pre-empted by the show of immovable sculpture by Carl Andre. The concert by the Chamber Orchestra of New York at the Hunter College Assembly Hall has been postponed because of the transit strike.

Seven Brink's parking meter collectors were charged yesterday with large-scale thievery of dimes and quarters. On the day they were arrested, they allegedly had 300 pounds of coins $5,177 in their cars from the day's runs.

There is special pathos in the fate of Angkor, the great temple complex that symbolizes Cambodian civilization. The same natural and human catastrophe that threatens the survival of the Cambodian people is also devouring their past. According to an Associated Press report from the jungle site.

YOUNG hopefuls with acoustic guitars and sheafs of original songs are showing up in New York City in sig nificant numbers again, drawn by a stable and thriving folk club circuit, increasing public attention and the chance of being discovered by a major record company.
MOLLY PICON, who makes a lively present of her long past, was at Town Hall last weekend with a vi vacity and vigor that should carry her through three shows there tomorrow and Sunday.
Moody's Investors Service reduced its rating of California state bonds yesterday, saying the bonds "can no longer be considered of prime investment quality."
The number of cracks found in undercarriages of New York City's fleet of 754 subway cars manufactured by Pullman Inc. has almost doubled in the last year, according to the Transit Authority.

Bach's The Art of the Fugue provides the inspiration for "Nine Fugues," a series of dances that will be presented this weekend by the Battery Dance Company at the Theater of the Open Eye, 316 East 88th Street. Jonathan Hollander is the choreographer.

PITTSBURGH, April 10 Ronald Reagan defended himself today against reports that he consistently makes inaccurate statements in campaign speeches, and he denied that he had shifted his position on the Olympic boycott.

Governor Carey joined Mayor Koch yesterday in seeking $50 million in Federal aid for small businesses in New York City that have been hurt by the transit strike. The Carter Administration, however, has been demurring, Federal officials said, for fear of offending organized labor in an election year.

BOSTON, April 10 (UPI) Rick Middleton, Don Marcotte and Brad Park scored second-period goals to highlight a 42-shot barrage and lead the Boston Bruins to a 4-1 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Penguins, evening the teams' National Hockey League first-round playoff series at one game apiece.
ONE of the pieces played by Jane Ira Bloom, the saxophonist, and her trio at the Chelsea Encore Cabaret last Monday evening was her own composition, "I Got Rhythm but No Melody."

The Performers' Committee for 20thCentury Music has been giving a series of concerts in Alice Tully Hall under the title Continuum, which has included retrospectives of the creative output of various 20th-century composers.

WASHINGTON, April 10 A Federal board monitoring the Chrysler Corporation's financial situation reported today that the company had significantly underestimated its potential losses for 1980 and its need for Government assistance.
In Dr. Nita Lutwak's psychology class at Bernard M. Baruch College, three students watched a slide show yesterday in a classroom in which 30 normally sit.
DETROIT, April 10 The location reportedly chosen by Volkswagen for its second American automobile assembly plant was farmland populated largely by people of German descent just 30 years ago.

The National Football League yesterday issued its 1980 schedule of 224 regular-season games, which begin Sunday, Sept. 7, an opening day that features a clash in Pittsburgh between the Steelers and the Houston Oilers, intradivision rivals.
OTTAWA, April 10 The Canadian Government announced today that it had chosen the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's F-18 fighter plane for its air force at a cost of about $2.5 billion.

PEKING, April 4 Late last year the leaders of the Songshuzhen coal mine in northeast China realized they were still 100,000 tons short of their assigned production quota. To make up the difference, they held several pledge-making rallies, offered bonuses to miners and began work in an unexploited, dangerous pit.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr. vowed today to fight to prevent Senate confirmation of President Carter's nomination of a black Virginian to a United States judgeship. No blacks have served on the Federal bench in Virginia in 100 years.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Adm. Stansfield Turner, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that in three separate instances he had personally approved the use of journalists for secret intelligence operations but that none of the journalists had been pressed into service.
PARIS, April 10 Algeria has suspended deliveries of natural gas to France as part of its campaign for higher prices, French officials disclosed today.

Canada's multibillion-dollar order for the controversial McDonnell Douglas Corporation's fighter jet is expected to provide a major lift for the aircraft manufacturer, which, analysts say, has had more than its share of troubles recently.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board today tentatively approved World Airways' bid to provide nonstop service from Boston to London's Gatwick Airport, beginning June 1. Trans World Airlines is now the only United States carrier in the Boston-London market.
HARTFORD, April 10 The State Senate tonight approved $160 million in new or higher taxes, including an increase in the sales tax and a new levy on major oil companies operating in Connecticut.

Ron Luciano has retired after 11 years as an American League umpire and has signed a contract to serve as commentator for NBC broadcasts of major league baseball games this season.

LIMA, Peru, April 10 Peru and four Latin American allies called today on countries outside their area to help evacuate and absorb the thousands of Cubans who have sought refuge in the Peruvian Embassy in Havana with the hope of emigrating.

New York City has prepared extensive plans to help people during the transit strike. They involve the use of private buses and commuter rail lines on expanded schedules, car pools and designated bicycle and pedestrian lanes. Additionally, many traffic regulations have been modified, parking restrictions have been eased and group riding in taxis is permitted.

In a system that is almost a mirror image of their New York neighbors', Democrats in New Jersey will gather on Sunday to pick their candidates for delegates to the Presidential nominating convention.

WASHINGTON, April 10 In the last few days, many of the most prominent newspaper editors in America have been listening here to all the major Presidential candidates and other political stars. The editors are not going home in an excessively joyous mood.

The Chemical New York Corporation reported yesterday that it had a 5.9 percent increase in first-quarter earnings before security transactions, to $32.5 million, or $2.06 a share, from $30.7 million, or $1.94, in the comparable 1979 quarter.

MOSCOW, April 10 (UPI) Two Soviet astronauts successfully docked their Soyuz 35 space capsule with the Salyut 6 laboratory in earth orbit today, completing the first difficult phase of their mission.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had earned $100.6 million, or $1.18 a share, in the first quarter of the year, up 20.9 percent from the $83.2 million, or 96 cents a share, that it made in the first quarter of 1979.

IN his next film, Volker Schlondorff, who is in New York for "The Tin Drum," his adaptation of the Gunter Grass novel, will deal with a theme that German film makers have seldom touched on although it is a central political and so cial issue the division of Germany into two countries.
Forty-second street bustled on a lovely spring day yesterday as two groups of concerned citizens made a pitch for its future and passers-by enjoyed the sunshine and some impromptu entertainment.

Through the 80 games of the National Hockey League's regular season, Phil Esposito was the closest thing the Rangers had to a consistent center. Ulf Nilsson missed 30 games because of a neck injury.

The Seagram Company Ltd., pressed to decide by 5 P.M. today whether to accept a $2.3 billion Sun Company offer for a little-known Seagram oil subsidiary, met yesterday under hectic circumstances with rival oil executives.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt condemned Israel's policy of establishing settlements in occupied Arab territory as "unfounded, ill-conceived and illegal" today and warned that they constituted "an invitation to further violence and unrest."
LOS ANGELES, April 10 New York City has its Rockefeller Center. Kansas City has its Crown Center. And Chicago has its Illinois Center. Finally, Los Angeles is to have a center, too.
MEXICO CITY, April 10 (Reuters) Mexican oil prices will remain at $32 a barrel during the second quarter, the state oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, said today.

DETROIT, April 10 (AP) The number of automobile workers on indefinite layoff will rise slightly next week. But the total of workers who are idle will decline through recalls of those on temporary layoff.

JERUSALEM, April 10 Israeli officials today portrayed their army's invasion of southern Lebanon as a defensive action without a time limit, aimed at screening their northern frontier from infiltrating Palestinian terrorists such as those who took children hostage Monday at the border kibbutz of Misgav Am.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The nation's estimated orange harvest was a record 265.5 million boxes, up 26 percent from last season's crop of 210.5 million, the Agriculture Department said today.

A simple question lies on the table when the United States Olympic Committee meets with its House of Delegates in Colorado Springs this weekend. Polls attest that two out of three Americans want their athletes to stay home.

WASHINGTON, April 10 In a classaction suit filed today, seven former United States servicemen are seeking to overturn Veterans Administration rules governing disability benefits for radiation victims. The suit was filed on behalf of military personnel ordered to clean up debris after the Hiroshima and Nagasaki atomic blasts in 1945 and assigned to nuclear test sites from 1946 to 1962.

MILWAUKEE, April 10 (AP) Sixto Lezcano hit a two-run homer in the fourth inning, then smashed a bases-loaded homer with two out in the ninth to power the Milwaukee Brewers to a 9-5 season-opening victory over the Boston Red Sox today.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 10 (Reuters) The Turkish Parliament failed to elect a new president for the nation today for the 25th time in nearly three weeks. No legislation can be discussed or passed until a president is elected.

WASHINGTON, April 10 The Small Business Administration ruled today that Brooklyn's Hasidic Jews did not qualify as a "socially and economically disadvantaged" group despite its poverty, thereby barring them from a program designed to assist the poor.

BALTIMORE, April 10 (AP) Roger Carr, expressing a desire to live closer to his family for the rest of his National Football League career, says he will not report to the Baltimore Colts for the 1980 football season.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted today to issue a limited operating license to the North Anna Unit 2 nuclear power plant in Virginia, the second new operating license issued since the Three Mile Island accident.

WASHINGTON, April 14--The United States Navy's presence in the Indian Ocean has begun to pose serious problems, officials said today.

WASHINGTON, April 14--Harold M. Williams, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the agency had "reasonable assurance" that no brokerage firm or publicly traded company was in jeopardy or "financial difficulty" because of last month's silver panic.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 14--New loans for Latin American borrowers are being delayed because the United States Congress has not yet authorized a replenishment of capital for the InterAmerican Development Bank, the bank's annual meeting was told here today.

After their record swing toward lower interest rates last week, the credit markets paused yesterday and then gave back a little ground. Even so, Treasury bill rates in the Government's weekly auction yesterday dropped to their lowest levels since February.

WARSAW, April 14--In an apparent effort to bridge the rift among West European Communist parties, Poland appealed to them today to submerge their differences and attend a meeting scheduled for later this month in Paris.

NEW DELHI, India, April 14 (AP)-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi escaped assassination today when a knife thrown by a man standing six feet away in a crowd outside Parliament House narrowly missed her, Indian authorities said.

WASHINGTON, April 14--Piling up delegates steadily in caucus states, Ronald Reagan now has more than half the total of 998 he needs to win the Republican Presidential nomination, and no other candidate has even a tenth of the necessary total.

Net in the latest quarter included an extraordinary gain of $6.8 million, or 26 cents a share, the company said.

New York, in which the Court ruled that the police need a warrant to enter a suspect's home to make a routine arrest. The majority opinion was by Associate Justice John Paul Stevens. The city is asking New York's corporations and foundations for $1 million to replace the money that Mayor Koch wants to cut from the city's budget for summer arts programs this year. The action has set off a debate about both the wisdom and correctness of the city's making a financial plea to private corporations.

BREMERHAVEN, West Germany, April 24--The France, a Ferrari of an ocean liner, was turned over to its new owner today as the Norway, refitted all white and cornflower blue and as sleek as a racing yacht on the outside but a kind of enormous tourist bus below decks.
GENEVA, April 24--Switzerland will represent American interests in Iran in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Washington and Teheran, the Swiss Foreign Ministry announced tonight.
PEKING, April 24--The Chinese Olympic Committee announced today that it would boycott the Summer Olympic Games in Moscow.

Two Bronx youths who pleaded guilty to burglary charges stemming from a 1978 fire they were accused of setting that left seven persons dead in an apartment building were sentenced yesterday to up to five years in a secure juvenile detention center in Goshen, N.Y. The two youths, Rafael Torres of 941 Intervale Avenue and Hector Velez of 936 Intervale Avenue, were 14 years of age at the time of the fire.

A rejected candidate for a delegate's seat at the 1980 Democratic National Convention obtained a court order yesterday seeking to block a caucus at which delegates are to be chosen from the 18th Congressional District on Manhattan's East Side on Sunday. JUDITH JAMISON, for many years Alvin Ailey's most celebrated dancer, has often flirted with the idea of a Broadway musical. In fact, three years ago she actually became involved with one, only to see the whole affair collapse before it got as far as Broadway.

Charging that hospitals in New York have been improperly discharging psychiatric and medical patients to adult homes with no facilities or staff to care for them, Councilman Antonio G. Olivieri introduced a bill yesterday that would bar transfers to adult homes without the city's approval.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24-- With the United States and the Soviet Union abstaining, the United Nations Security Council sharply rebuked Israel today for its recent armed incursion into southern Lebanon.

ALBANY, April 24--Virtually overnight, New York State's 1980-81 budget has ballooned from $13.982 billion to $14.965 billion--on paper, at least. Without even a blink from the Legislature, local aid expenditures went up by $61 million and state agency budgets grew by $989 million.
About a dozen robots will appear this weekend at the International Conference on Robotic Futures at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University, Flatbush and DeKalb Avenues.

A memorial service for Robert E. Garst, a former assistant managing editor and city editor of The New York Times, will be held Thursday at 10 A.M. at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 24 (UPI)--The Government today announced a retail price increase for petroleum that ranges from 9.5 percent to 25 percent, the third increase in a year.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 24--Despite a warning from the Justice Department that they faced stiff fines and possible criminal penalties, hundreds of Cuban-American boat owners converged on this small island today and prepared to set out for Cuba, where friends and families were waiting for transportation to the United States.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 25 Peter Vidmar, who had competed twice previously in the national gymnastics championships without finishing higher than 13th, tried a third time tonight and beat a field of better known competitors with an all-round score of 114.9 points.
BUENOS AIRES, April 25 (AP) The Argentine Government, reversing its steps toward a freemarket economy, announced measures today to head off the collapse of major banks and companies indebted to them.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 25 (AP) A Federal district judge has invalidated all of California's laws regulating nuclear power plants on the ground that the Federal Government has exclusive power over nuclear energy.

Security at Gracie Mansion was increased yesterday following an early morning incident in which a man jumped over a fence, broke a window and stuffed his copyrighted articles on management inside Mayor Koch's residence, the police said.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 25 Deputy Attorney General Charles B. Renfrew announced today that a Federal grand jury had found no cause to prosecute any of the police officers who shot and killed two alleged terrorists on an isolated mountain in 1978.

New Jersey will not again prosecute a 36-year-old black man who had been convicted three times and had won a retrial each time in the slaying of a white police officer during a racial disturbance in Plainfield, N.J., almost 13 years ago, a state official said yesterday.

HAMBURG, West Germany, April 25 Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that a bank loan being negotiated for the Hunt brothers should be used only to resolve their financial problems and not for renewed speculation in the silver markets.

LONDON, April 25 Two wives of hostages being held at the American Embassy in Teheran expressed dismay today at the aborted attempt to rescue the captive Americans.

TOKYO, April 25 (Reuters) Foreign sales of Japanese bonds exceeded purchases by $112 million in March, compared with net foreign purchases of $251 million in February, the Finance Ministry said today. Foreign sales of bonds in March fell to $638 million, from $723 million in February, while foreign purchases fell to $526 million, from $974 million.

A 100-foot crane boom atop a high-rise office building being renovated in midtown Manhattan toppled across a street and crashed into the upper facade of another office tower yesterday afternoon, sending tons of steel girders and brick debris cascading onto the street below.

WASHINGTON, April 25 It was 4:57 P.M. in Washington yesterday when President Carter, speaking on the telephone from his hideaway study next to the Oval Office, directed Defense Secretary Harold Brown at the Pentagon to terminate the rescue mission in Iran.

A mentally retarded man was found bludgeoned to death early yesterday in the bedroom of his apartment in the Bronx, the police said. The victim, Horrace Muldrow, 47 years old, who lived with his sister and brother-in-law at 1460 Washington Avenue, was found at 1:15 A.M. lying on his bed with a pillow covering his face. His apartment was ransacked and the door was unlocked. The police found a bloodstained wrench in the building's incinerator.

WEST BERLIN, April 25 (Reuters) Pope John Paul II has named Bishop Joachim Meisner of Erfurt as Bishop of Berlin, a nomination that will almost certainly make him the new head of East Germany's 1.2 million Roman Catholics, the West Berlin Catholic Church office said today. Bishop Meisner, 46 years old, will be installed May 17.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 William Bligh, the storied villain of the mutiny on the Bounty, was a frutrated father figure whose feeling for his lieutenant, Fletcher Christian, compelled him to the beratings that ultimately drove Christian to mutiny. Or so says 38-year-old Glynn Christian, the great-great-great-great grandson of the mutineer.

A 57-year-old man died yesterday in a one-alarm fire that swept through the attic of a private house in Jamaica, Queens, the Fire Department said. The victim, Henry Butler, who lived in the two-story frame building at 110-17 158th Street, was declared dead at the scene of multiple burns, a spokesman said.

HAVANA, April 25 (Reuters) In a message to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, President Fidel Castro has expressed the Cuban Government's "fraternal solidarity" and said Iran faces "serious threats of armed aggression by the Yankee imperialists."

Citibank, New York's largest bank, reduced its prime lending rate yesterday by one-quarter point, to 19 percent, joining the majority of American banks, which have already moved to that level. The Chase Manhattan Bank and the Wells Fargo Bank of San Francisco reduced their prime rates to 19 percent in separate moves earlier this week.
WASHINGTON, April 25 The majorparty candidates challenging President Carter for the White House laid aside their political criticism of him today after the failure of his Iran rescue mission.

WASHINGTON, April 25 The family of John Earl Graves, one of the captives held in the American Embassy, said today it received assurances this morning from Teheran that no retribution would be directed against the hostages for the failed American rescue mission.

HAVANA, April 25 Dozens of small boats continued their all-day, all-night parade into the nearby port of Mariel today to pick up Cubans who want to go to the United States.

HOUSTON, April 25 The New York Mets got their first look tonight at the most expensive and maybe the most glamorous pitching staff in baseball, and paid the price: only four hits and a 7-4 loss to the Houston Astros.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) The Justice Department yesterday dropped its efforts to alter voting arrangements for the 1980 South Carolina State Senate elections and announced an intensive review of five pending voting rights cases in light of a new Supreme Court decision.

NORTH KINGSTOWN, R.I., April 25 (AP) Workers at the Electric Boat plant in Quonset Point have decided aginst joining a union, a company spokesman said today. Balloting was conducted by the National Labor Relations Board, and 90 percent of the 3,300 employees voted, the spokesman said, with 53 percent voting to stay nonunion.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25 (AP) A walkout that could have crippled the resort hotel industry here was averted today when representatives of major hotels tentatively agreed on a new contract with six labor unions.

Rosie Ruiz, who insists that she ran the New York and Boston Marathons from start to finish, had her New York finishing time of 2 hours 56 minutes 29 seconds invalidated yesterday by the games committee of the New York Marathon.

Pan American World Airways reported a loss yesterday of $74.9 million for the first quarter, despite a 60.3 percent rise in operating revenues and a 5.3 percent rise in passenger miles flown. The company attributed the loss to "soaring fuel prices" that it could not recover through higher fares.

LOS ANGELES, April 25 (AP) In a commemoration of 1.5 million Armenian Christians who were massacred 65 years ago in Turkey, 6,000 survivors of the slaughter and their children and grandchildren marched through Los Angeles yesterday. WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) Two companies have agreed to recall more than a half-million hair dryers and styling combs manufactured with asbestos, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) The Government announced today that it was lowering the interest rate on Government-backed home mortgages a full percentage point, to 13 percent. It was the first decline in more than three years.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)--The Environmental Protection Agency today ordered manufacturers to conduct new studies into possible health risks of 2,4-D, a weed-killer found in the herbicide Agent Orange.

Against a small slam, it may be necessary to develop a trick that can be cashed when the lead is regained, so a lead from a king or a queen may be appropriate. Against a grand slam, this does not apply.

The Overseas Press Club of America named the winners of its 1979 awards for excellence in foreign news coverage yesterday, with Iran-related coverage dominating the field with nine awards and citations.

Harper Row's union employees held a rally at noon yesterday outside the book publisher's offices at 10 East 53d Street to show solidarity during contract negotiations; the current pact expires tomorrow. There was a strike three years ago that lasted several weeks; this time there is talk of a week's extension of the contract. The parties are far apart on basic money issues.
LONDON, April 29 (UPI)--Sir Freddie Laker has won a third transAtlantic route for his Skytrain service, this time between London and Miami, a spokesman for Laker Airways said today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29-- Through the first two rounds of the Stanley Cup playoffs, Pete Peeters, the goaltender of the Philadelphia Flyers, was the little boy with his finger in the dam. He turned back the offensive surges of the Edmonton Oilers and the New York Rangers and went into tonight's semifinal game against the Minnesota North Stars with a 1.54 goals-against average.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 29 (AP) --One of the five servicemen hurt in last week's attempt to rescue the hostages in Iran was released by an Air Force medical center today, visited his four hospitalized comrades and then left for his home in Florida.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP)--Dr. James L. Quinn 2d, a Northwestern University professor and a former consultant in nuclear medicine and radiology to the World Health Organization, died yesterday at his home. He was 46 years old.

Nominated for a recent Oscar, Bette Midler lost out to Sally Field. But the ebullient actress and singer probably has no time for regrets. Miss Midler is on a promotional tour for her autobiography, "A View From a Broad," published by Simon Schuster.

TOKYO, April 29 (AP)--The Japanese Government has tentatively decided to remove tariffs on imported automobile parts, the Kyodo News Service reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 (UPI)-- The California Public Utilities Commission granted a record $1.2 billion annual rate increase today to the Pacific Gas and Electric Company to offset rapidly rising costs of natural gas and oil.

Sugar futures rose yesterday to the daily permissible trading limit in all but one contract month as traders evened up their positions in advance of the last trading day in the May contract, analysts said.

WASHINGTON, April 29--President Carter's plan to register young men for a military draft was approved today by a surprisingly wide margin by a Senate Appropriations subcommittee. The 8-to-4 vote cleared the measure for action by the full Appropriations Committee, probably within a week.

FORT LEE, N.J. GONE is the taste for residential construction that changed the skyline of this Hudson River borough in the last two decades. The new direction is toward the construction of office buildings.
SACO, Me., April 29 (AP)--Residents of this city in southern Maine voted today to repeal a controversial ceiling on property taxes.

ALBANY, April 29--Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, asked the State Legislature today to stay out of what he called "a grubby money quarrel" between film distributors and film exhibitors over the practice of "blind bidding."
WASHINGTON, April 29--President Carter named Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine today as Secretary of State to succeed Cyrus R. Vance.

The body of a man found April 18 in the trunk of a car on a Bronx street was identified yesterday as that of Antonio Capronigro, a reported "captain" in the Philadelphia-South Jersey crime "family" headed by Angelo Bruno until he was murdered March 21.

KUWAIT, April 29 (Reuters)--Gunmen in cars fired several shots today at a motorcade carrying Iran's Foreign Minister, Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, to a meeting with the Emir of Kuwait. The visiting minister escaped unhurt.

TEL AVIV No sign identifies the gray fortress near the sea and yet everyone knows what it is. Habitues begin arriving late at night. Presto.

With some investors evidently taking encouragement from plunging interest rates, the stock market extended its rally yesterday. In the absence of pronounced movements in most stock groups, numerous issues responded to earnings reports and dividend announcements.

WASHINGTON, April 29--American military officials said today that all the paramilitary agents infiltrated into Teheran for the rescue of American hostages had quietly slipped out of Iran the same way they entered early this year, by posing as European businessmen.

Canadian newsprint production totaled a record 782,000 metric tons in March, up 5.9 percent from February and 4.2 percent higher than in March 1979, the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association announced yesterday.

Christopher called "one of our happiest days in a long time."

The price of gold fell in Europe yesterday but gained in New York in slow trading. Gold for May delivery rose $15 an ounce, to $523, on New York's Commodity Exchange and advanced $10, to $522, in later trading at the Republic National Bank of New York.

Mr. Deak will perform in works for woodwind, brass and string with the Queens Symphony Orchestra CETA Chamber Ensemble. Admission is free. Information: 592-2405.

HOUSTON, May 1 (AP)--Gil Morgan beat the rain, wind and lightning with a six-under-par 65 today in the incomplete first round of the $350,000 Houston open. After play resumed, it was eventually suspended by darkness.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)--Russell E. Dickenson, a 33-year veteran of the National Park Service, was chosen today to head the agency in an action that received widespread praise from conservation groups.

The New York Stock Exchange should be completely reorganized, becoming a subsidiary of a new corporation that would be owned by the members of the exchange, a committee of the exchange's board of directors recommended yesterday. A committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday recommended toll increases on all bridges and tunnels operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

LEXINGTON, KY. GRAY hours crept by, and grown men dreamed in the barns that may have been painted when the late Col. Matt Winn watched the first Kentucky Derby from the tailboard of his father's wagon. Of the 13 horses waiting to start the 106th Derby tomorrow, most shared the same two barns on the backside of Churchill Downs; all the men shared the same dream.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 2 Ed Figueroa, the former 20-game winner who threatened to quit if not traded by next Wednesday, said today he had changed his mind and would remain with the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) The Pentagon today ordered a start on full production of the bomber-launched cruise missile and decided that the Boeing Aerospace Company, a unit of the Boeing Company, should build all 3,418 weapons planned.

WHITE PLAINS, May 2 Neighborhood and civic associations in the Westchester County town of Greenburgh have won the right to put political notices and pamphlets in private mailboxes. SAN JUAN, P.R., May 2 (UPI) Luis Munoz Marin, the founder of Puerto Rico's present commonwealth status, was buried in the mountain town of Barranquitas today in a funeral attended by thousands of Puerto Ricans and foreign dignitaries. TOKYO, May 4 (AP) The Soviet Union reportedly has set up an army division headquarters on one of four contested islands north of Japan in an apparent attempt to establish a "permanent" military presence.

THE northern, or golden, tilefish, a deep-dwelling species whose flesh has been likened by some to scallops or lobster, is rarely encountered by the average marine angler because its habitat is so far offshore.
Avon Products Inc., a cosmetics and jewelry company, increased its quarterly dividend to 75 cents a share from 70 cents, payable June 2 to shareholders of record May 15.

HARTFORD, May 4 (AP) If the general election were held this week, President Carter and Representative John B. Anderson would each win 32 percent of the vote in Connecticut, according to a poll published today by The Hartford Courant.

With a small band and a large turnout, Democrats in the New York State Senate threw a fund-raising party yesterday in hopes of turning their minority into a majority for the first time in 16 years.

Ethyl alcohol has become many Americans' favorite potential substitute for imported oil. Sugar, grains and root crops can all be easily converted into this clean-burning fuel suitable for car engines.

The Convenience and Safety Corporation announced yesterday that it was withdrawing its bid to build 4,100 bus shelters in New York City and said it was "leaning towards" not bidding on any future contracts to build such shelters in the city.

PEKING, Monday, May 5 (Reuters) Hua Guofeng, the Chinese Prime Minister and Communist Party Chairman, will head a special Chinese party and Government delegation to attend President Tito's funeral in Yugoslavia, the Foreign Ministry in Peking announced today. The prime minister will also visit the Yugo slav Embassy in Peking to express his condolences, the ministry said.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 4--Ronald Reagan and President Carter won clear victories in yesterday's Texas Presidential primaries, but each success was blemished with signs of weakness for the general election in this battleground.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Executives of the automobile industry say they support the idea of forming a partnership with the Government to do basic research but do not want to let the Government on the assembly line.

Two Queens bus lines, the Queens Transit Corporation and the Steinway Transit Corporation, warned Mayor Koch yesterday that they would discontinue service to their 125,000 daily riders on May 13 if they did not get increased funds from the city to cover labor costs.

THE Gang of Four is such a clever name for a rock band that it seems amazing nobody thought of it before. DETROIT, May 5 Sales of American-made passenger cars by the Big Three auto makers plummeted 38.8 percent in the final 10 days of April. The poor showing meant that Detroit's car sales for April, normally the auto industry's best selling month, were down almost a third from April a year ago.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 5 Joan Lind of Long Beach, Calif., earned a spot on the Olympic team today by capturing the singles event in the women's Olympic rowing trials at Lake Carnegie. She covered the 1,000-meter course in 3 minutes 43 seconds, two boat lengths ahead of Judy Geer of Dartmouth.

Mary Mitchell Dodderidge, who with her husband, Robert R. Dodderidge, raised thoroughbred race horses at their farm in Bluemont, Va., died Wednesday in Winchester, Va., after an illness of two months. She was 57 years old.

WASHINGTON May 8 The White House said today that President Carter's special trade representative, Reubin O. Askew, would ask the makers of the Japanese Datsun automobile to negotiate with the Ford Motor Company for the plant that Ford owns and is vacating in Mahwah, N.J. Mr. Askew is now in Japan.

AKRON, Ohio, May 8 (UPI) A Comman Pleas judge found himself under fire today for issuing an order that apparently attempts to bar all the Ohio news media from publishing information about a case related to Akron's public corruption scandal.

Marjorie Bertha Schell, a director of the Cambridge Family and Children's Service and a fund-raiser for various charities, died yesterday at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 68 years old. She lived in New York from 1935 until 1978 and was also a trustee of the Bank Street School in New York and of the Putney School in Putney, Vt.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) The Justice Department announced today that its antitrust division had recommended denying two Chattanooga, Tenn., newspapers temporary approval to combine their printing and commercial operations.

MILWAUKEE, May 8 (AP) Don Money belted a three-run homer, Gorman Thomas added a two-run shot and Sixto Lezcano homered with the bases empty, powering the Milwaukee Brewers to a 9-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

Governor Carey and Mayor Koch were among 500 people at the simple half-hour memorial service for Arthur Levitt yesterday at the Union Temple alongside Prospect Park in Brooklyn, where Mr. Levitt, the six-term former New York State Comptroller, had worshiped most of his adult life.

The nation's largest retailers reported yesterday that their sales, already slower this year than last, worsened further in April compared with April 1979. The decline is expected to reinforce opinion that the country is in a recession.

WASHINGTON The United States strategic petroleum reserve was conceived by Congress in the wake of the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo as a means of protecting this country against future cutoffs of foreign oil. THE other Islanders have their names lettered neatly above their dark wooden lockers at the Nassau Coliseum, but above Ken Morrow's locker his name has been scrawled with a black marker on a strip of adhesive tape that has turned gray.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 Walt Disney Productions and Ringling Bros. and Barnum Bailey Circus today announced a co-venture to put on a Disney ice show to play arenas across the country starting in August 1981.

ALTHOUGH doctors deal with illness every day, many often cannot fully understand its impact because they are not the patient. Illness isolates people Pain and other symptoms may be hidden. Anxieties, uncertainties about the future and fears of death often are suppressed. Feelings are closeted.

Lillian Roth, the actress and singer who entertained millions for more than half a century and who inspired many others with her struggle against alcoholism and mental illness, which she related in her 1953 book "I'll Cry Tomorrow," died last evening after a long illness at De Witt Nursing Home, 211 East 79th. She was 69 year old.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has agreed to pay a $500,000 civil fine for not recalling 400,000 tires that it knew would probably fail Federal safety standards, the Transportation Department reported today.
The dollar lost strength in currency trading yesterday as American interest rates continued to decline. Gold prices rose in Europe but fell later in the day in New York.

MANCHESTER, England, May 12 (Reuters) A mass funeral for 121 victims of an air crash in Tenerife in the Canary Islands last month was held today in this northern English city. Only 34 of the bodies buried in a communal grave could be identified.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 In the nearly naked downtown headquarters that the Kennedy campaign has just taken over from the defunct national campaign of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., Oren Teicher, a young Congressional aide turned campaign worker, tilted back a straight chair and clasped his hands behind his head to ponder.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 12 Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said today they hoped for quick approval of the authority's plan to raise tolls from $1.50 to $2 on its two tunnels and four bridges.

A factor that could influence the future of the Spanish language in the United States is the accelerating drive for statehood in the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.

Bishop Henry Know Sherrill, one of the nation's most influential church leaders after World War II and the retired Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, died Sunday at his home in Boxford, Mass. He was 89 years old.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 12 (AP) J.B. Stoner tried to collect $2,000 from two police undercover agents for the 1958 bombing of the Bethel Baptist Church, a prosecutor said today at the opening of Mr. Stoner's trial.

Wayne Hicklin, former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Avon Products Inc., the producer and distributor of cosmetics and toiletries, died Sunday at his home in Poughquag, N.Y. He was 68 years old.
MOSCOW, May 12 Yuri Lyubimov's politically daring new "The House on the Embankment" opened Saturday at the avant-garde Taganka Theater, little damaged by its intensive going-over by the censors.

WASHINGTON, May 12 The Supreme Court today defined for the first time the "interrogation" of suspects in criminal cases that it prohibited in its landmark Miranda decision. It held that an offhand remark by a police officer did not violate a murder suspect's rights even though the remark led the suspect to incriminate himself.
WASHINGTON, May 12 A Presidential Emergency Board recommended a settlement today that would increase the wages of carmen on the Port Authority Trans-Hudson line by 25.5 percent over three years.
